1.q_string: Negative deviation from Raoult’s law is observed in which one of the following binary liquid mixtures?

At \(25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), the solubility product of \(Mg(OH)_{2}\) is \(1.0 \times 10^{-11}\). At which \(pH\), will \(M g^{2+}\) ions start precipitating in the form of \(M g(O H)_{2}\) from a solution of \(0.001 \mathrm{MMg}^{2+}\) ions?

\(1.00 \mathrm{~g}\) of a non-electrolyte solute dissolved in 50 \(\mathrm{g}\) of benzene lowered the freezing point of benzene by \(0.40 \mathrm{~K}\). The freezing point depression constant of benzene is \(5.12 \mathrm{~K} \mathrm{~kg}\) \(\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\). The molar mass of the solute is:

What is the heat of the solution of sodium chloride from the following data?

The hydration energy of \(\mathrm{Na}^{+}=-389.4 \mathrm{~KJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)

The hydration energy of \(\mathrm{Cl}^{-}=-382.3 \mathrm{~KJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)

The lattice energy of \(\mathrm{NaCl}=776 \mathrm{~KJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)
Which one is not equal to zero for an ideal solution?

Calculate the mole fraction of ethylene glycol \(\left(\mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{H}_{6} \mathrm{O}_{2}\right)\) in a solution containing \(20 \%\) of \(\mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{H}_{6} \mathrm{O}_{2}\) by mass.
Calculate the molarity of a solution containing \(5 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{NaOH}\) in \(450 \mathrm{~mL}\) solution.
Which one of the following is incorrect for ideal solution?

The freezing point depression constant (Kf) of benzene is \(5.12 \mathrm{~K} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\). The freezing point depression for the solution of molality \(0.078 \mathrm{~m}\) containing a nonelectrolyte solute in benzene is (rounded off upto two decimal places):
Calculate the molarity of a solution containing \(5 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{NaOH}\) in \(1 \mathrm{~L}\) solution.
Calculate molarity and molality of \(6.3 \%\) solution of nitric acid having density \(1.04 \mathrm{gcm}^{-3}(\mathrm{H}=1, \mathrm{~N}=14, \mathrm{O}=16)\)

q_option: Both Assertion and Reason are correct and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are correct but Reason is not the correct explanation for Assertion.
Assertion is correct but Reason is incorrect.
Assertion is incorrect but Reason is correct.
1.q_string:
Assertion: The molecules of the dissolved gas present in a liquid gain kinetic energy as temperature is raised.

Reason: Gases tends to be more soluble in liquids as the temperature is raised.

At \(25^{\circ} C\), the solubility product of \(M g(O H)_{2}\) is \(1.0 \times 10^{-11}\). At which \(\mathrm{pH}\), will \(M g^{2+}\) ions start precipitating in the form of \(M g(O H)_{2}\) from a solution of \(0.001 M M g^{2+}\) ions ?

q_option: They all have the same osmotic pressure.
1.q_string:
Consider the separate solution of \(0.500 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{H}_{5} \mathrm{OH}(\mathrm{aq}), 0.100 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Mg}_{3}\left(\mathrm{PO}_{4}\right)_{2}(\mathrm{aq})\),

\(0.250 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{KBr}(\mathrm{aq})\) and \(0.125 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{Na}_{3} \mathrm{PO}_{4}(\mathrm{aq})\) at \(25^{\circ} \mathrm{C} .\) Which statement is true about these solutions, assuming all salts to be strong electrolytes?
Which of the following binary mixtures will show negative deviation from Raoult's law?
Mixing up equal volumes of \(0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaOH}\) and \(0.1 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{COOH}\) yields a solution that is:
Osmotic pressure is \(0.0821\) atm at a temperature of \(300\) \(K\). Find concentration in mole/liter.

A gas \(X\) with a disagreeable odour reduces silver nitrate solution to give metallic silver and is itself oxidised to \(Y\). \(Y\) is a dibasic acid with reducing properties. It is slowly oxidised in air to a tribasic acid \(Z\). Though \(Z\) is a tribasic acid, it behaves in an aqueous solution mostly as a dibasic acid. When a mixture of \(X\) and \(\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}\) is subjected to electric spark, \(\mathrm{Z}\) is obtained.

q_option: \(X\) and \(Y\) have similar structures and dipole moments
\(X\) and \(Y\) associate or dissociate in solution
\(X\) and \(Y\) are immiscible and hydrogen bonding occurs between them
1.q_string: For a system containing two liquids \(X\) and \(Y\), Raoult's law is obeyed when:

At a particular temperature, the vapor pressures of the two liquids \(A\) and \(B\) respectively are \(20 {kPa}\) and \(30 {kPa}\). If \(2\) moles of \(\mathrm{A}\) and 3 moles of \(\mathrm{B}\) are mixed to form an ideal solution, the vapour pressure of the solution at the same temperature will be (in \({mm}\) of mercury):
Osmotic pressure of a solution can be increased by:

Dry air is first passed through a 0.1M KCl in water & then through 6M KCl solution. Which among the following statements is/are true :

(i) Dilute solution will show a loss in weight.

(ii) Change in weight of the dilute solution is proportional to its vapour pressure.

(iii) Concentrated solution will show a gain in weight.

(iv) Change in weight of the concentrated solution is proportional to its vapour pressure.
For \(1 \mathrm{M}\) solution of \(\mathrm{HA}\), the dissociation constant \(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{a}}\) in terms of vant Hoff factor (i) can be written as :
Choose the correct statement with respect to the vapour pressure of a liquid among the following.

The diagram below shows the \(\ln \left(P_{\text {vapour }}\right)\) vs. \(1 / T\) for four substances. The Clausius Clapeyron equation describes this relationship. The Clausius-Clapeyron equation is :

\(\ln \left(\mathrm{P}_{\text {vapour }}\right)=-\frac{\Delta \mathrm{H}_{\text {vapour }}}{\mathrm{R}}\left[\frac{1}{\mathrm{~T}}\right]+\mathrm{C}\)

According to the graph, at high temperatures, which substance has the greatest vapour pressure?

1.1: Direction: In the question below is given an assertion followed by a reason. Then consider the assertion followed by reason together and decide which of them follows from the information given in the assertion.
